title: What is AI?
content: Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to machines or systems that can perform tasks that normally require human intelligence

title: What is Generative AI?
content: Generative AI (GenAI) uses models to generate new content such as text
source: or code based on input prompts. Common examples include ChatGPT

title: What is RAG?
content: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) combines generative AI with a retrieval system
tags: allowing the model to pull context from a knowledge base before generating answers.

title: What is Agentic AI?
content: Agentic AI represents autonomous AI agents that perceive

title: How does a Core Agentic Loop work?
content: The agentic loop follows Perceive → Reason → Act → Learn. The agent senses its environment
column6: and adapts from outcomes to improve.

title: What are some prompt engineering best practices?
content: Prompt engineering involves designing input prompts for AI models to get desired outputs. Best practices include defining roles

title: Single-Agent vs Multi-Agent Systems
content: Single-agent systems handle sequential tasks. Multi-agent systems use multiple specialized agents (Planner

title: What tools support RAG implementations?
content: Common tools include LlamaIndex for indexing documents
tags: LangGraph or CrewAI for agent orchestration
source: and vector databases like Pinecone or Chroma for embeddings.

title: How do you prevent hallucinations in AI?
content: Prevent hallucinations by grounding outputs in trusted sources
column6: and reviewing outputs through human-in-the-loop processes.

title: Measuring ROI of Agentic AI
content: Measure ROI by tracking time saved on tasks
column6: and revenue impact from automating multi-step tasks with autonomous agents.
